description.text: This is a direct drive adaptation and improvement to the Makibox A6 Feed System. It utilizes an improved an non-dulling hobbed gear which is attached to a new Nema 17 motor (not the one with the brass adapter that comes with the Makibox A6). This drive is a remix/redesign of the Makerbot "Spring-loaded Replicator 2 Drive Block" mechanism specifically for the application of an improved Makibox "Zen Drive" system. I take no credit on the original aspects of the design, however would like to accept the credit for the composition of the redesigned and implemented parts.

This project requires:
  • One of each STL file to be printed.
  • One 13mm OD Hobbed Motor Sleeve
  • Three M3 x 0.5, 25mm long cap screws
  • High Resistance, 3/8" x 3/4" compression spring
  • Aluminium Bushing (OD, ID, W)
    • It is noteworthy that the "Motor Plate V1" requires some extensive amount of support and is recommended to be built on a printer that can handle soluble support methods. Design implementation and production in progress. I have not had a lot of time to spend on it lately.

comments.text: Design looks good. Are you still working on it? I was designing something that at least operates very similarly.
comments.author: trget

comments.text: Thanks! I've kinda put it off to the side for a while and haven't spent much time with my Makibox. I have tended to get frustrated with the mechanics that were implemented in its design and so I would like to one day reinvest my time in redesigning parts of the machine. But alas I never seem to have the time I once did. The extruder that I designed/implemented above worked well for me, so I thought I share it. By all means take it and revise/redesign it!

description.text: A simple wedge to support the body/frame of the printrbot Simple maker's edition (wooden frame) to help prevent flexing or bowing when extending the X and Y axis.  If you are getting unexplained vertical lines after extending you X and Y axis,  first change slicer to print infill before perimeters.  Then use this wedge to prevent flexing of the body.  (you should aready have it secured or using front and rear stabilizing legs.)

Print 2 pieces.
Secure your simple to prevent rocking or shaking, then place this wedge on each side, right in front of the x axis motor. (largest gap under the simple.)

Yep, a discus.  
My son has taken an interest in middle-school track and field and has decided to throw the discus.  Throwing the discuss well at this level depends more on having good form than being strong, so practice helps.  But practicing with a competition discus has potentially lethal side effects for unwary passerby's at the park.  
So I made my son this light weight practice discus that will merely stun, not kill, said passerby's. My son can throw it around and practice his technique without having to go a real netted-in discus throwing ring.  
It is the size and shape of a 1kg Junior discus, but substantially lighter.  Paradoxically it seems harder to throw flat.  
Print four copies of the STL and glue them together.  Make the seam on the top and bottom perpendicular.  Then go and act out your Olympic fantasies.

.2mm layer height - 3 shells - 15% infill  
Print 4 copies.  
Glue them together with the top and bottom seams running perpendicular to each other.  
Bright colors are important to finding it after a throw.  If your kid throws it 50 feet and it then rolls another 20 feet before falling over into a divot in the grass, he will spend a lot of time trying to find it again if it is not a bright color.

comments.text: The lack of rim wieght is the issue with your disc not flying flat or smooth take your same design and hollow it out till you are within a 1.5 inch edge of the rim the overall disc will now be even lighter but he will throw much smother and farther because the disc can now rotate quickly around a lightend center point and create lift.

description.text:
I got my hands on an Arduino Due and off course I had to design another stand to add to my collection (check out my other arduino stand designs). I learned from my previous designs and therefore made this one a bit beefier. So it is easier to print and off course stronger. The Arduino Due and the Mega should be the same size and form factor. This stand should fit both.
It does NOT fit the Freetronics etherdue. 04/05/2014 Update:

description.text: This "poster" is made out of acrylic and it is actually for my history teacher. We had to write an essay about our five most favorite Americans and then we had to define what it means to be an American. In my essay, I suggested that being American means that you are simply crazy. Crazy enough to fight for freedom, crazy enough to try (and might I add succeed) in building a working democratic nation, crazy enough to sacrifice our lives to help cure poverty in other countries. The things that Americans do are very crazy. Sometimes, our craziness isn't always good for example, like when we sacrifice our lives to stuff our ideas down the throats of countries who like their way of life. Sure, we have our faults but overall, we are a nation of crazy nice, crazy funny, crazy strange, crazy determined and just plain crazy people. With this idea in mind, I made this poster for my history teacher and in the future, I will make a frame for it. There are 50 stars on it for the 50 stars on our flag and 13 "veins" which represent the 13 stripes on our flag. You can actually put little pictures in the holes that surround the eagle too=)

First, to make this design, I went on google images and choose a nice picture of an eagle. I then use Illustrator and Photoshop to make the eagle black and white so that it could be rastered onto to acrylic. Next, I put a 10 1/2 in by 10 1/2 in square around the eagle so that the laser would vector cut the square. After that, I made the "veins" by using the pencil tool to draw varied spaces that would also be vector cut. Finally, I added the text and the 50 stars which would also be rastered onto the acrylic. Then, I printed this image onto clear acrylic using a CNC Laser. Because the image was so clear and see through, I made a new Illustrator file and copied this whole image, deleted the text, the eagle and the stars and kept the lines that had to be vector cut so that the card stock would be the exact background/outline of the acrylic.

I tackled the gutz: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3196 Update 02010-05-20
I added zipped versions of the skull files. Want a Godzilla-headed, skull-headed, Ganesh-headed or any-headed Cupcake Transformerâ€½ Here are the files. This thing is a mash-up between the head of jmillerid\'s Cupcake-winning \"Cupcake Transformer\" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2865 and bryanbrutherford\'s sick \"Chester Copperpot\" skull http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2567. Two great tastes that now taste great together! For even more transcendental transformative transmutative fun, mash up the Transformer\'s \"back.stl\" to kustomize its gutz.
  • LOLCat head with cheeseburger gutz
  • Pirate head with treasure chest gutz
  • Daft Punk head with â€½â€½â€½ gutz
    • If someone doesn\'t beat me to it, I\'ll tackle the gutz soon. Go! BTW, the attached skull1.stl file is a MakerBot-sized and oriented version of \"Chester Copperpot.\"

I\'m a SCADdie, so my weapon of choice is OpenSCAD. Use the \"head.scad\" file as a starting point.
  • Download the \"head blank.stl\" and \"head.scad\" files
  • Open \"head.scad\" in OpenSCAD
  • Edit the import_stl lines to import and position your favorite \"head\" STL
  • Render, then export mashed-up object as STL file
  • Skeinforge STL file
  • Print Gcode file
  • Replace Transformer head with kustom one
  • Enjoy!

You will also see 3 tabs that need to be snapped off, these tabs help hold the thin edges to the build surface and prevent it from pulling away and warping.

• Download money clip.stl
  • Print with default MakerBot Replicator settings with out raft or suport.
  • Snap off the 3 tabs.
  • Slide over a stack of folded bills.

description.text: perpetual motion machine , torque converter right side and weight feed left side base design

Gravity driven in a horizontal circular motion, machine derives its power from a series of four falling weights, that generates more than enough kinetic force to continually power the machine in loop. The weights used to power this machine could be the size of a dime or as big as a car tire. I first laid the design out and machined on three compact disks powered by quarters, the second machine was fashioned out of particle board which does not hold its shape due to moisture it was powered by weighs that i cast out of led. Powering this machine with cork, if the machine and workings was microscopic in size and powered by cork you would have a Hadron. Inspired by Johann Ernst Elias Bessler
(alias Orffyreus, 1680 â€“ November 30, 1745)

title: Doctor Who pendant for two color printing

description.text:
I remixed the original by splitting the letters and lamp from the base.  Then I added some small supports to tie the letter and lamp parts together for easy reassembly. Now it can be printed in two colors!  
I would recommend scaling these two parts up about 10% along the X-axis before printing with a filament printer (if you are having trouble with the narrow parts).  I use 100% fill and it is still a fast print.  
In the picture, I used a blue marker to color the top of the transparent letters only.  This gives it three colors and looks cool.

• Print the first part.
  • Print the second part.
  • Glue the first part to the second part.
  • Show it off!
    • Optional: Use markers to add more colors.

author: willnewton

description.text:
Compatible with Lego City Trains.  
Redone from scratch to be as simple as possible.

Prints fine in PLA and ABS.
Use support for the overhanging track ends.

This is a model reconstructed from an MRI scan of a gourd using ImageJ and Meshmixer. This awesome blog has posted a ton of animated gifs of MRI scans of different plants and vegetables: http://insideinsides.blogspot.com/2010/08/bitter-gourd-melon.html

Not all of the gifs from http://insideinsides.blogspot.com work well. Try to find one with a lot of frames, > 150 seems to work well. Get ImageJ from: http://rsbweb.nih.gov/ij/
Meshmixer from: http://www.meshmixer.com/ Steps:
  • In ImageJ: File -> Import -> Animated Gif
  • Plugins -> 3D -> 3D Viewer
  • Display As: Surface, Color: White
  • File -> Export Surfaces As -> STL (binary)
  • Load it in Meshmixer: fix it*
  • Can be complicated, basically select the outside, expand to connected, invert selection, edit discard (to get rid of interior noise) See also: plane cut.

title: Custom UART 2102 Interface Case with 'cheat" window

description.text:
Updated version of design by gnabeyama: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:136359
This version uses that one's lid, so you'll need to download:
"usb_case_top_repaired.stl", (I've added a copy on the Thing Files page as of 3/1/2015) Customized this to fit one of the newer 6-pin USB UART 2102 Adapters floating around ebay for a mere .45 cents.

Changes include:
  • raised walls to accommodate higher pin-headers.
  • moveable board-retainer that prevents the chip from receding into the case when USB port is plugged in.
  • & a cheater's window on the bottom so you can see which pins are labelled which without the need to remove the case.

5/7/14 - Update:. Uploaded an STL version per franic's request.
Uploaded v2 "customuart_with_window-a-v2",Thing and .STL v2 revision notes:
longer window (so you don't mix up voltage)
improved visibility (window view-angle) 1/31/15 - Update:.
Uploaded "custom_uart_openwindow-v3.stl" an open-window reference version intended for those who can't make the window adjustments or get this to print with a window, also tweaked the design slightly.. v3 revision notes:
fully open window (non-adjustable .stl)
more efficient print (quicker to finish, less filament) v3.1 - minor fixes to bridge over the usb port.
This was my first design here. with literally less than 24-hours of 3d printing under the belt.. (nonstop, of course!)

Just slide the window piece till it lines up with your pin-labels. Remember to keep the window away from the solder-points.  
Same procedure for the retaining-peg for the board, simply slide it to match your boards clearance.

remixed_from.author: dynai
remixed_from.title: Universal Spool Roller (86 to 102 mm Width)

description.text:
The Expandable Spool Holder is free standing, holds as many spools as you would like, and holds most spools of different widths and diameters.  The holder will fit spool diameters with a minimum of 6.125", with no real maximum.  I have used it for the following standard spools: Makerbot RepRap and Printrbot wooden spool. I plan to design other attachements such as: filament guide, feet for flat surfaces, and attachments for hanging the entire assembly.  You can quickly adjust the width with a set screw rather than having to move a nut on all thread.  
*Note: The newest revision has an "indent" so the bearing screw may be tightened down without holding the bearing from spinning (thanks for the recommendaton Lightn).  HOWEVER, I HAVE NOT PRINTED this revison to test it, but the only change is the indent.

Print List:
-12-278_filament_spool_holder (2/spool)
or
-12-278_filament_spool_holder_minimalist (2/spool) - uses less plastic, but is less durable
or
-13-102_filament_spool_holder (2/spool) *see end of description before printing this revision Buy List:
-1/2" Tube (I used AL, but any material will do). Length equation is (Number of Spools * 1/2" + Total Width of all Spools). I made mine 18" base on area limitations.
-10-32 x 3/4" Bolts (4/spool) - these hold on the bearings
-10-32 nylock nuts (4/spool) - these are optional as the bolts should self tap into the printed parts
-10-32 x 1/2" Bolts (4/spool) - these are the set screws for sliding on the 1/2" pipe (I didn't use any as a friction fit was enough)
-Bearings 8mm bore x 7mm W x 22mm OD (4/spool) Links to purchases: -Bearings - I bought these and they work fine (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBGTK6/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00)
-1/2" AL Tube - I picked mine up at a local hardware store, but here is a link if you want to purchase it online. (http://www.amazon.com/Aluminum-6061-Seamless-Round-Tubing/dp/B009ACD2E0/ref=sr_1_4?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1349396777&sr=1-4&keywords=5%2F16%22+aluminum+tube) Instructions:
  • Print 12-278_filament_spool_holder (2/spool)
  • Buy parts on list above
  • Put bearings onto small protusion on printed "12-278_filament_spool_holder (2/spool)"
  • Use 10-32 x 3/4" bolt to hold bearing in place (see pictures)
  • Cut 1/2" tube to your desired length
  • Slide printed parts (with newly added bearings) onto the tube so the bearings are all inward
  • Set spool on the assembly and print!

description.text:
I liked ljon's stand but it was a bit unstable and had some geometry problems, so I added a support to the back and did some clean up.  
This has been working great for our Nook and Kindle.

I really wanted to print all the parts but due to time I stuck with the hardware and it works well. You will need: M4, #6 or #8 rod about 58mm or 2.25" long x2
M4 or #8 screws at least 20mm or .75" long x2
10 matching nuts
Threadlocker (superglue will work) You may need to file or drill out the holes slightly depending on your hardware. Assemble as shown, the key is to threadlock all the nuts, otherwise it will fall apart. On the arm pivot, threadlock the nuts slightly loose so it can move freely.

title: Our Next Home
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is our vision for the new home we hope to build, complete with maker space and small workshop/3D printer room. It is designed entirely in OpenSCAD. Each floor and each of the roof structures can be printed as a separate part. We've used the prints to share our ideas with a builder and architect, and they generated a lot of feedback from others as well. There are OpenSCAD functions for the doors, windows, cabinetry, wood stove, appliances, toilets, etc.

The OpenSCAD code is far from perfect, but hopefully can be followed if you are so inclined. Most dimensions are in feet, thicknesses and heights are generally in inches. At the top level, everything is scaled to be printed by a machine controlled in mm.  
When all layers and details are modeled the number of elements exceeds the 1000 element OpenCSG limit, so the code is sprinkled with "if (print>0)}" commands that disable internal details when viewing the whole house.  
Another quirk of the code are all the mirror() commands, put in to reverse the x-axis, making x=0,y=0 the front left corner of the house and x=27 feet 4 inches,y=40 feet the back right corner.   
Every file's been printed except for the entire house as one piece.

comments.text: I have a slow printer (20mm/s for most features). The first floor took almost 9 hours, the second took 6 1/2 hours, and the total print time was 48 1/2 hours, not including all the time between prints. I finished the last piece 7 days after the first, loosing 2 days when I ran out of natural ABS (It's a happy accident that the dirt and basement are brown). A newer printer could cut the time down by a factor of 5 or so, but to really speed things up you'd have to reduce the scale. A large print bed would be a big help, allowing more floors to be built at a time.

comments.text:
It has an odd syntax, that's for sure, but it's a very useful tool and there's a logic and efficiency in the syntax. The trick is to find a semi-colon and then read right to left. For example:
Â  translate([1,0,0]) scale([2,1,1]) sphere(r=1);
means start with a radius 1 sphere, stretch it in the X direction to double the length, and move it 1 unit in the X direction.

description.text:
This is a simple mold to allow people to make their own sidewalk chalk crayons. It is inspired by the Bloxen, Sidewalk Chalk Mold 'thing'.
My boys used to use this stuff on our driveway all the time and they loved it!

Print, fit together, hold together with a rubber band, pour in plaster-of-paris colored with powdered tempera paint. Let harden for ~24 hrs. Demold. Go outside and color! http://www.zheng3.com/2012/10/01/casting-about-for-new-ideas/ Note the SCAD file is rather ugly... :p NOTE: For demonstration purposes I melted five red crayons and poured it into the mold. It works for wax too. :p

comments.text:
The alignment spheres and tabs would fit easier if you put in some clearance. .1mm on all sides would be good. I rewrote the bottom to be the same as the top except to remove the union, and increased the clearance for the holes. The side walls had to be thickened to 3mm to accommodate.
Also, I've found that a fudge factor of 0.01 still produces that coincident face "shimmer", but 0.1 does not.
I know it's been a few years since you put this up, but you should totally make this customizable! If you've lost interest, I can do it.

This is a lens holder for a lens that is 50 mm in diameter. A semicircular slot 3 mm wide holds the edge of the lens. Adjust the SCAD file for the lens and mounting hole dimensions you need . Lens holders are useful for demos and optical experiments. The specific lens shown in the photos is "50mm Optical Glass Lens Collimator Plano-Convex for Led Projector" which is Ebay item 161126916191. On my printer, the slot ended up at 2.7 mm wide, about 0.3 mm too narrow for the 3.0 mm lens edge, so I had to scrape it out a bit with a knife point. Unless your printer is more accurate than mine, you might want to enlarge the slot a bit in the SCAD. For a different 50mm lens holder that fits on a yardstick, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49942
For a similar holder for a 75mm lens, see
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1917482 The blue item is what I printed from the enclosed file. The black one is a similar shape I made by hand from Kato polymer clay, which turns from clay-like to a hard plastic (PVC) after baking 10 minutes at 150 C. That was my very first try at a clay model- crude, but functional.

I tried printing this in ABS two different times on a Makerbot dual with 110C heated bed. The first time it worked fine, and that's the one you see in the photo. However I printed without a raft and it cracked off the bed just at the moment that the printer finished, so I got lucky.  The second time it popped free at about 1/5 done, so maybe I need a raft or some different settings.  
The hand-carved polyclay version is a lot less clean looking, and more work to make, but it also does the job and didn't require a printer at all!  Although having the actual 3D item in hand was very helpful in carving out the rough copy.

This connects 4 cold cathode florescent for omni directional light for macro photography. Like these: http://www.xoxide.com/dual-white-cold-cathode-kit.html This isn't the brightest but it works if you happen to have 4 tubes and need light for macro photographs.

• Print
  • Clean up undersides of the bridges with a razor or file
  • Insert tubes and 1/4 inch wooden dowels
  • Zip-tie the wire out of the way
    Note: With a trip to Radioshack and some soldering and heat shrink tube you can make an adapter to use a 12V power supply (like and external hard drive power supply) See note at bottom for additional details.
    • Optional Reflectors
  • Cut paper (card-stock or thin cardboard is best)to height based on the slot in the reflector clip, and the width based on the available tube minus the clips
  • Score paper lengthwise with a ball point pen
  • Rub the paper on the edge of the table to curl it like this -> (----
  • Use a glue stick (spray adhesive is best) to attach tin foil to the inside of the reflector
  • Wrap string around the paper to form it to something like the parabola slot on the clip
  • Insert the ends of the paper into the slot in the clip
  • Clamp the ends on with a bar clamp extremely carefuly
  • Add super glue (cyanoacrylate) to the slot
  • Wait till you think its dry then wait 20 more min (because if you drip that crap on your white picture taking surface you will not be happy)
  • Remove the thread while looking for uncured super glue
    Note: The reflectors will flare out this is OK, the parabola is not centered around the tube, so the flared out portion will still be directing light in the right direction
  • Clip the reflectors on
  • Take some pictures
    • Note: Power adapter
    Barrel jack - make sure the size on the barb in the inside is the right size, there are two different ones. Check the power supply, is it positive center of positive barrel?
    Molex connector - Black = Common, Yellow = 12V Note: The clean laboratory look of the included test pictures is honestly because of the lights. Note: Shot with Sony HX9V

title: Harbor Freight LED flashlight to handlebar clamp

description.text: Stick a cheap (sometimes free!) HF 3.5" 9-LED mini flashlight onto your handlebars.  The flashlight diameter is .960" and the bar diameter is 1".  Both can be changed in the OpenSCAD file if you'd like.

I haven't had a minute to try printing this yet, but you should be able to open each of the two *half.stl files in replicatorG and just hit build (for each one separately). Print the two halves (one half is sized for the .960" diameter flashlight, while the other half is sized for a 1" handlebar). Glue the two printed halves together and you're ready to snap the light to the clamp and the clamp to your bars. That's the idea anyway. The hf_flashlight_clamp_overview.stl file probably isn't useful for printing - It's just so the rendered image shows up as a whole, glued together clamp. If you're making changes to the OpenSCAD file and generating your own STL files, you should know that the dimensions are in inches (where you'd normally use mm in OpenSCAD). If you are doing this, then follow these steps before printing:
  • Export the STL file after compiling in OpenSCAD
  • Open the file in ReplicatorG
  • Scale by 25.4
  • Use the Rotate feature to make the model "lay flat"
  • Use the Move feature to Center and Put on Platform

This is modern look given to footwear wore by ancient Sadhus in Indian culture.You can made real one out of wood. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/6LwqumeBmvI

BEAS If you own an Acronym jacket you'll be familiar with the Gravity Pocket. You may also be party to the same problem I had - that if you're not paying attention, whatever you're trying to eject out of the pocket can, er, fully eject... on the floor. The BEAS (Ballistic Ejection Arrestor System, haha) is a simple anchor that sits inbetween the Gravity Pocket zips, and can be attached via a piece of Kevlar thread or fishing line to a phone / device case and prevent that inadvertent launch of your phone to the ground. OK so it may be a bit embarrasing looking when the device is dangling from your sleeve after a botched 'deployment', but it's a hell of a lot better than a cracked phone. You should measure the cord (especially if you're using several lengths of finer Kevlar sewing thread for example) to somewhere between 8 - 10" for optimum function - i.e. for the BEAS functionality to work while the cord doesn't get too much in the way. Obviously, check whatever cord you're using can bear the stress of the device weight when it's being ejected. You can see the BEAS in action here (with a longer arrester cord for effect): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zy2sACB173s V3.9 is probably the last version of BEAS, and is therfore posted as a finished Thing. I'm currently working on a different route for Gravity Pocket bugfixing which is based around a Gravity Pocket insert which has a gravity assisted lock and rail-guided ejection system (...hence no more string) for an iPhone 5/s case - the idea being that instead of the BEAS route of mitigating failed ejections, I make ejections much more consistent in the first place. Version History:
V1 - Rough proof of concept (never posted). Designed and printed in little more than a few minutes, initially to establish viability of idea.
V2 - Initial fully functional version (removed). Demo video/photos were shot with V2.
V3 - Refined with more pronounced 'head' to allow usage of thicker cords and also to prevent BEAS falling out easily (removed)
V3.9 - Current. Swept down edges so a lot less likely to catch on loose clothing / luggage. Build Particulars:
Although it doesn't need supports, V3.9 is quite tricky to print - you'll need cooling going full blast for all the overhang action that's going on. However it is printable.

description.text:
On the ikea wardrobe (see pic) the knobs for hanging your clothes onto are fixed in such a way that a special metalpiece is inserted between the panels and is then fastened with a screw coming from the knob.
The knobs on the Ikeawardrobe are too big for the standard loop on your clothes. If you want to exchange the knobs to smaler ones youÂ´ll soon discover that there are screws with a diameter of 8mm built in. As the standard is 3mm i designed a small part with an opening for the 3mm nut. Using this part you are able to use the satndard knobs on this wardrobe without alteruing the threads or the knobs.
For all the University of TN fans. Go Vols!

After problems with inconsistent filament diameters in my RepRapPro Ormerod I made an extruder block that includes a spring for tensioning. It uses a long 3mm screw, nut and a tension string on a long lever arm. I've implemented this one with great results - it handles variations in filament with ease. This works well with variable filament diameters. Smooths out the action of roughly printed gears. Makes cleaning the hobbed insert a snap - Undo the bottom spring screw, flip the back up and clean away! :) As mentioned on forums.reprap.org it makes the mounting of iamburny's Herringbone gears (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242536) a bit easier because you can mount the gears separately, then mesh them together once complete.
The spring I've used came from a fairly strong action ball-point pen - the lever action increases the effect of the spring, so it works well for me and others.

description.header: EDIT: Some discussion on the RepRap forums indicates that there is a large difference in spring strength in pens and that they can be under strength for this purpose - A suggestion is the springs that can be found in the plunger of products like soap dispensers - refer to http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?340,524181,page=2 for the ongoing discussion. :)
description.text: The STEP files are included in case you want to make a modification - in which case share & share alike (and keep me informed - I'd like to know) :)

In this version the Feeder part has a wider feed pipe to allow for the PTFE insert to run all the way up to just before the hobbed insert. This is supposed to decrease the resistance on the filament and stop wear on the extruder.

Print the version you want - Most people will only use the 'Extruder' files - either the PTFE liner version or the standard - that has all the parts necessary. The 'With support' files include simple support that should print well with most slicers and should be easily removed.
Whichever files you use, you'll need a 'motor' part, a 'feeder' part and probably the 'tongue' part.
Screw the feeder to the motor using an M3 screw and nut through the hinge at the top - optionally using thin washers between if your print has the space.
I found that I had to work the hinge a little bit before it was a smooth action, but don't need the washers myself.
Build the extruder as per the original RepRap plans. Make sure that the tongue is properly inserted and anchoring the Bowden tube correctly, then optionally anchor that in place with a cable tie or screw.
Insert the long M3 screw at the bottom with the spring between the head and the bracer near the filament entry point. Tension the spring by sending through filament - can be done by hand by turning the large gear. Specifically try to stop the filament to make sure the hobbed insert doesn't slip on the filament.

The only breakage problem I've had has been with the 'transparent' ABS, which is not very flexible, and that was with a Prusa with a direct feed, no bends and a less than ideal feed system. comments.text: Another thought. One of the problems I find with the Ormerod is that if I leave the filament in the extruder for a few days without printing anything, when I next come to print it breaks off (or has already broken off) in the extruder. So how about a quick-release mechanism that I can use to release the pressure on the filament when I finish printing? In its simplest form, this could be a slot for the screw instead of a hole in the front part, along with a circular recess for the spring to seat in. Alternatively, a slot in the back part, retaining the hexagonal nut trap. Either way, the tensioning screw could be disengaged without the use of tools.

comments.text:
That's an interesting problem. I've never had my filament break inside the extruder - even after a while of non-use. I wonder if it's to do with the humidity in the UK?

I'm not sure if I'll get a chance to make that sort of change in the short term, but I might be able to do a tappable hole for the M5 thread - a little something in exchange for the excellent work you do on the firmware!

comments.text:
I've been using V2 of this extruder for a couple of weeks now, and am very happy! 2 things I'm going to change:
1) The top hinge on the large gear side should be countersunk so that the spacer nut for the large gear isn't required. This will allow other gears like the interesting helical gears.
2) Where the feed tube for the filament enters at the bottom, I think I should have a guide to keep the two parts aligned, rather than relying on the screw hinge at the top for alignment.
I was worried that moving the large gear closer and further away from the small gear wouldn't work well, but I'm happy to say that this isn't a problem - I've managed to feed filament that varies between 1.5 and 2mm with no problems.

This case keeps your buck converter safe, holds a USB plug, and provides magnetic contacts to attach homemade solar panels.
This case is part of a larger guide to make a converter for easy to make solar panels.

I printed with 0.2mm layer height. The model is so small that infill settings don't matter much. After printing, the case should be able to snap and stay together through some tricky designing.
Follow my instructables guide on making this converter.

title: Iris Door Box v1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I'd recommend printing my newest version over this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:140048 I got a ton of requests for this at Maker Faire NYC, so here you go. I really liked emmetts iris box but was having trouble putting it together and the pins kept breaking. Using his as an inspiration, I built this from scratch to use flat head screws. This version will work very well after some tweaking. I have included a small and large version. There is also a shorter version of the small base to make it as compact as possible. One disadvantage of this design is that it can't be scaled up or down unless you figure out what size screw will ride in the track properly.

I have been using 5% fill and 1 shell with good results.
You will need #4 x 1/2 flat head metal screws for small version and #6 for the large version. They must be flat heads or it probably won't work.
After printing, layout the iris blades and put a small piece of tape on the top to hold them all together.
Put the iris leaves on the pins and lay the gear ring on top.
Put screws in through the bottom and get them started.  Screw them all in until they just stop.
REMOVE THE TAPE!  I constantly forget and can't figure out why the iris won't work.
Now adjust all the screws in/out until the iris moves smoothly.  This can be a bit of a pain.  I find that after screwing in all the way, backing them off 1/4 - 1/2 turn is a good start.  Usually 'all the way' is further than you think.  There shouldn't be much play between the ring and iris leaves.
Depending on the quality of your print you may have to clean up the edges of the blades so they close properly.

title: Drybox feeder for moisture sensitive filaments

description.text:
For using moisture sensitive filaments(Nylon, Polycarbonate, PVA, questionably PLA) , rather then keeping the spool in storage and trying to pull off what you need, just use this to feed from moisture resistant storage directly to the print head. Be sure to check out the BOM in the gallery Use PhillipTheMobster's filament stand inside and its perfect!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318527

Drill (3) 1/4" holes though your storage container where you want the parts to be, 1" spacing between the holes. Then use an 8-32x 3/8" pan head machine screw a nut to clamp the two pieces together(subsitute M4 x 10mm for metric) . Use sealant if you desire, though I suspect airflow will be minimal, even without sealant. The outlet uses a tubing push connect, designed for 1/8" BSPP threads. The 'Oversize' outside fitting is for printers that print holes undersized, 'Nominal' outside fitting is 0.020" smaller in diameter for printers that print closer to nominal or oversize. I used McMaster PN 5225K504 for my fitting to 6mm OD tubing that my printer uses, and a Snapware brand 23 cup storage container to fit the large spools from makergeeks. Use whatever containers will fit your application. UPDATE:
PhillipTheMobster's filament stand is the perfect height for the 23 cup snapware, and leave space on the bottom for a desiccant pouch/container
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318527 The huge makergeek.com spools still rubbed ever so slightly. But you can fix it easy a hair dryer to heat the plastic and a blunt object to spread the walls where it rubs by an 1/8" on either side or so and it turns freely. If anyone else has problems with the leg piece not slicing right, comment here and I'll upload my .stl with the fixed leg.

comments.text: Great design!  I am almost finished with this project, but it seems like a tight fit with the spool holder you mentioned on the details page.  Are you using yours with or without the spool holder?  There should be no reason the spool wouldn't spin unless the friction is too great inside the container.  Thanks for this design.
comments.author: Sonderklasse

title: Peg board shelf bracket spacer. Got droopy shelves?

description.text:
NOTE: This was designed in Autocad with units set to inches. Please remember that you need to give it a scale of 25.4 if you want it to print to the correct size. Sorry about that. I will likely do everything in metric from now on. I'm a silly American. ;)  
The pegboard I have is somewhat thin and it causes my shelves to droop a bit. Well that and overloading the shelves with junk.   
I was tired of things slowly falling off the shelves and fixed it with this little spacer. If you can lift up the shelf a tiny bit, you won't even need to remove the shelf to install it. In fact the weight of the shelf helps greatly to get these to snap round the back of the bracket.   
Should work with wire brackets with a diameter between .15" â .215" or roughly 4 â 5mm. If you have a bracket with a smaller or thicker diameter you should be able to easily scale it up at print time.
Just print and install.

description.text: Skeletal human foot, derived from the excellent BodyParts3D database. Sliced near the ankle to provide a flat surface for printing (toes up!) Credit: BodyParts3D, CopyrightÂ© The Database Center for Life Science licensed by CC Attribution-Share Alike 2.1 Japan. Interactive database and hundreds more .OBJ source files can be found here: http://lifesciencedb.jp/bp3d/?lng=en .ZIP of .OBJ files: https://docs.google.com/open?id=0B_3DyBhHQQc2X2t5ZXNpbkZqNTA Journal article describing the BodyParts3D project: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18835852 http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/content/37/suppl_1/D782.full-text-lowres.pdf My post describing methods to isolate anatomical features and get them ready to print: http://craig.bonsignore.com/2012/10/07/open-3d-human-anatomy/

• Print

  • Enjoy

  • Share

    LiPo Holder prepared for Graupner GR-24 receiver and a large 5000 mAh 4s battery similar to this one: https://www.mikrocontroller.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=87&products_id=440&zenid=8de52278cdd3768e13888b9339edbb4b

For the Print I used black PLA for the Centerplates and transparent "Natural" for the torus since I think there should be some awesome LED illumination later on ;) The centerplates are solid (100% infill) and the Torus has 5% infill since most of the stiffness comes from the outline. Outline has 0.4mm - same with the top and bottom layers To assemble the parts you need

description.text:
My first step to designing a full miniature.
The pattern on the boots has a width of .25 mm.
They sit on a 25mm base.
Everything is parametric in the OpenSCAD file. You can make them longer, shorter, wider, higher, as you like. So you should be able to make e.g. a women's shoe while the design stay in place. I used a neat trick to make the pattern on the irregular shaped shoe. To make a line I cut out a cube with the thickness of the line width (xline) out of the body. Than I scale the original body by (x_dimension-xline)/x_dimension, in every direction, and superimpose it. The stl was repeared (and shrunk by a factor 5 in size) by netfab.Thanx. The zip contains all files. Enjoy.

Print.
No assembly requiered.
Enjoy.

description.text: This light-duty buckle can be attached to straps or belts for a unique and secure fastener for homemade bags, purses, or even belts. The latch mechanism releases "airplane-style" rather than by squeezing or push-button, by gently lifting the flexible latch and pulling the two pieces apart. (See airplane instructions dance video: http://youtu.be/DtyfiPIHsIg?t=52s) Not for personal restraint!

comments.text: I made this buckle today on my CUBE 3D printer. It printed out very nicely, something most of the buckles I have tried to make have not done. HOWEVER, the hinge end of the spring catch component (larger part) snapped apart immediately, while I was merely washing the glue off it from the printing. It was too thin and definitely needs to be strengthened in this area. If strengthened I expect the buckle will work as intended. The idea is great. I hope you can fine tune it so I can use it!! Thank you.
comments.author: robrook

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback! That's a tricky spot for sure because it has to be thin enough that the release latch can flex to open but strong enough to take some stress. It sounds like your printer might have low layer cohesion which would cause that problem. Try printing without a fan blowing on it during the print, or with slightly higher extruder temperature. Either of these will increase the strength of your prints between layers, which is inherently the weakest direction. Let me know if that helps! Best, Michael

description.text:
• I updated files to make this a much better print. Split the body in half, because basically half of it is overhang. Much easier print now.
    • Who doesnt need half a dozen of these fast jinkers griefing the crap out of your opponent? Scaled correctly. Checked and everything slices correctly. You should be able to use the legs from the "Motorcycle Enthusiast," to sit in the Speedy Land Griefer.
  • Updated rear spoiler. Also, you should scale the "blast window" by about ~1.3
    • Still need - front antenna, Trying to stay in line with Games Workshop IP Policy. If any GW employee or representative wishes me to remove or alter any designs, let me know and I will comply with expediency. Below I’ve outlined how I tried to comply with their policies.
    .
    Overall - None of these are exact replicas. I tried to add abit of my own take on things or modification to the design. Ei kitbash it abit. Additionally, all models should just be used for painting practice. Practice messing up a paint job on a print, not your actual GW model.
    .
    Copyrights - I tried to make sure a “significant part” was not the same. Style, yes. Copied, no.
    .
    Trademark - I’ve removed all specific Trademarks. Ex: Aquila
    Non-commercial - I’m making no money from this
    .
    Professional Distribution - I’m not a professional artist, using any of these as a portfolio advertisement. Just a hobbiest tinkering
    .
    Damage our brand - Not doing that. GW IP is a pretty cool universe. Hence the reason I wanted to make models that “live” in it.
    .
    Make it clear you’re doing it unofficial - I’m doing this UNOFFICIALLY.
    .
    Use trademarks appropriately - I tried to remove all trademarks
    .
    Derivative Works - I believe most of these models would fall under derivative works, two are three models might not, but I think most do.
    .
    Non-commercial recasting and 3D printing - I have not scanned any of GW’s IP.

title: Fan Guard & Airflow Deflector for Makerbot Replicator

description.text: This is a single extruder version.

I printed this on a Replicator v1 with MakerWare - 'Medium' setting (0.27mm layer height) with support, 100% infill, 3 shells. Support didn't work very well, but it fit into place after a bit of cleanup with an x-acto blade and works great. if printing again, I would try the high quality setting or decrease the layer height to 0.15mm. Available on Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/g5SIhhnUpxP? 1) Prevents breakage of fan blades due to sticking objects into moving fan (aka fingers).
2) The Replicator extruder fan blows air onto parts as they're being printed, causing distortion, curling, etc. The fan shroud prevents air from being blown onto objects during printing.

description.text: This is a first draft of a design for an interlocking, 3D-printable, wearable shoe. Three files are attached: one of the inside of the shoe, which is meant to be printed using NinjaFlex, one of the outside of the shoe, which is meant to be printed using PLA, and one of both parts together. As a final touch, a piece of NinjaFlex filament can be used as the shoelace.

I designed this shoe on 3ds max as a final project for my Product Design Class at Lehigh University. I then 3D printed the shoe in a wearable size for my foot, and it was the second 3D-printable item I had ever designed and printed.

comments.text: Hi - I really like the concept and design.
comments.author: goldentuna1200

comments.text:
Measure or 3d scan your foot. Then, upload this shoe into http://tinkercad.comtinkercad.com (free and easy) or another CAD program. Use the ruler in the CAD program to measure the shoe. You can then resize the shoe in the CAD program, then print it out. Make sure your 3d printer is big enough to print a size 11. If not, you might need to use the CAD program to slice the shoe and print it out in halves to be glued back together later. In that case, ABS is easier to glue using acetone than PLA.
Also, if you absolutely want to make sure that the shoe fits, you can insert the 3d scan of your foot into the shoe's 3d scan. Then, use the CAD program to subtract the foot from the shoe.
If you don't have a 3d scan of your foot, measure your foot and then put a 3d file of a shoe last that has been resized to match your foot's dimensions inside the shoe. Then, subtract the shoe last from the shoe digitally using the CAD program. This subtraction is called a "boolean" operation.
Have fun!

description.text: Toy Puzzle Ball
STL Files of Puzzle Ball

Mounts the Bulldog XL Extruder rock solidly to the Z-bar of the K8200. Inspired by this. I wanted a simple solution that's ridiculously rigid, and at the same time doesn't force you to disassemble the printer; and this is it.

I printed with ABS 100 % infill for rigidity. Probably overkill, but I like being on the safe side.  
Disassemble the Bulldog XL Extruder and replace the plastic gear box cover (with the logo) with the bracket part. (I needed some silicone spray lubrication on the inside of the part to fit it.)  
Insert square M5 nuts (the same as comes with the printer) into the square holes and screw tightly to the frame with M5 bolts. I added serrated washers for extra security.

comments.text: I see in the original pictures you used a three-wheel design with two plates and fixed axles, but you've since moved to a single plate with a sprung axle integrated into the plate. Can you talk a bit about this design change, like your experiences and reasons behind the change?
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text:
The 2 plate design didn't provide a way to adjust wheel tension.
We soon changed to a split compression carriage. https://github.com/UltiBots/D300VS/blob/master/d300_carriage_mb.stl
Lately we have moved towards a design that uses and eccentric spacer and a belt tensioning mechanism. https://github.com/UltiBots/D300VS-PLUS/blob/master/d300p_carriage_bca.stl

description.text:
Classroom 3D printing is expensive and time-consuming. There's always more demand than capacity. It's the slowest step in the innovation cycle. Yet all too often students choose to print more versions of their designs than necessary rather than waiting to submit a job only once it's been sufficiently refined and a print is necessary in order to test and confirm their working assumptions.
Another common classroom challenge is how to motivate students to move beyond their comfort zones and how to reward them for doing so.
Forget Bitcoin. We're 3D'ers! So we use 3DBucks to optimize printer demand and motivate students to maximize their progress through each lap of the cycle. 3DBucks are credits that students must spend in order to print something. The cost of each print job is based on the amount of filament it consumes. Available denominations are 1 gram, 5 grams, 10 grams, 25 grams, and the special Dual credit. The cost of a job that uses both extruders on the dual-headed printer is based both on the amount of filament it consumes as well as a Dual credit.
You can give students some 3DBucks at the start of the semester, when a project is assigned or at some other point that makes sense in your classroom. 3DBucks encourage healthy saving, spending and design habits.They can also be used as rewards for good behavior, perseverance, helping others, winning a design contest, or any other deserving achievement.
Version 1.1: Made several changes based on users' input. The heads and tails of all denominations are separate STL files. A zip tie slot has been added in the upper left corners.
Thanks to Ollie & Mei-Mei for all your great ideas, feedback and refinements!
I print 3DBucks on our Makerbot using ABS. Temperatures are as expected; 230 at the tip & 100 on the bed.

comments.text: Yes, teachers will want to customize their currency, perhaps by adding lettering or other features to the STL they download
